Air Law.question: What are the minimum requirements for flying in cloud in gliders?
options: The occupants must wear a serviceable parachute and have been instructed in its use.
The pilot must have received instruction in the use of blind flying instruments.
Before entering cloud, the pilot must transmit position and height (QNH) on 130.4 MHZ.
All the above.

Air Law.question: What are the restrictions imposed on gliders flying within a MATZ. (Military Air Traffic Zone)?
options: No entry during the hours eight AM to five PM.
No entry while the MATZ is active.
None, so long as the ATZ is not penetrated.
None

Air Law.question: You are approaching a strange airfield and receive red flashes from the ground, what should be your actions?
options: Give way to other aircraft and continue circling.
Land immediately.
Do not land as the airfield is not available for landing.
Move clear of the landing area.

Air Law.question: Under what circumstances is a weak link not required in the winch / auto tow cable?
options: The launch is a hill top site where the conditions are likely to be rough and break the weak link on a regular basis.
The proven breaking strain of the launch cable is lower than that of the weak link strength required by the glider manufacturer.
The tow car is of low power.
The glider is a heavy two seater with a history of breaking weak links.

Air Law.question: What are your actions if you suspect any defect or damage to a glider?
options: Report it to the duty pilot before the next flight.
Report it to the duty instructor before the next flight.
Note the defect or damage in the DI book before the next flight.
Ground the glider until an inspector can check for defects or damage.

Air Law.question: What are the VMC rules when flying in class D airspace below 3000ft AMSL at 140 kts or less?
options: 1500 ft horizontally, 1000 ft vertically, clear of cloud and in a flight visibility of more than 8 Km.
1500m horizontally, 1000 ft vertically, clear of cloud and in a flight visibility of more than 8 Km.
1000m horizontally, 1500 ft vertically, clear of cloud and in a flight visibility of more than 8 Km.
Clear of cloud and in sight of the surface with an in flight visibility of more than 5 Km.

Air Law.question: When aerotowing, the tug rocks its wings laterally. What does this mean?
options: Release, you're at 2000 ft.
Release immediately.
Your air brakes are open.
The tug can't release.

Air Law.question: When two aircraft are approaching head on, each shall alter its course in which direction?
options: To the left.
Only the first to see the other need take avoiding action to the right.
Only one alters course to the right to save any confusion.
To the right.

Air Law.question: When two aircraft are converging at approximately the same height, who has the right of way?
options: The aircraft which has the other on its right has right of way.
The aircraft on the left.
Neither. Both must take avoiding action.
The aircraft which has the other on its right shall give way.

Air Law.question: Who has command of a tug / glider combination?
options: The tug pilot.
The glider pilot.
Neither, as there must be a captain of each aircraft.
The most senior of the two pilots.

Air Law.question: A glider shall not fly over any congested area below a height which would enable it to land clear of the area, or below 1500ft above the highest fixed object within 2000ft., which ever is the higher. Nor shall it fly over or within 3000ft of any open air assembly of more than 1000 persons (without specific CAA permission). When is there an exemption to the 1500 foot rule?
options: Never, the rule is rigid and must be adhered to at all times.
During normal take-off and landing and for life saving.
Only when excellent soaring conditions exist.
Only during a field landing.

Air Law.question: Which of the following statements is most correct?
options: Gliders shall give way to airships and balloons.
Gliders shall give way to balloons.
Balloons shall give way to gliders.
Gliders shall give way to aerotow combinations only.

Air Law.question: Above what height should oxygen equipment be carried and what height is recommended for its use?
options: 10,000 ft amsl and use above 12,000 ft amsl.
12,000 ft amsl and use above 10,000 ft amsl.
10,000 ft amsl and use above 10,000 ft amsl.
12,000 ft amsl and use above 12,000 ft amsl.

Air Law.question: What must all glider pilots carry on flights over 5 nautical miles from their gliding site?
options: A low level navigation chart.
Map(s) marked clearly with the controlled and regulated airspace.
A flight plan.
A serviceable parachute.

Air Law.question: Any accident resulting in death, serious injury or substantial damage to an aircraft must be reported to whom?
options: The BGA within 24 hours.
The Department of Transport AAIB.
The Police.
The Police and the Department of Transport AAIB.

Air Law.question: What is the maximum launch height allowed by the winch method without written permission from the CAA?
options: There is no limit.
60 metres.
2000 ft, but up to 3000 ft at a few notified sites.

Air Law.question: A glider is defined as being in flight during what period?
options: From when it leaves the ground until it touches down again.
From the signal 'take up slack' until it comes to rest after landing.
From when it first moves to take-off until it comes to rest after landing.
From the signal 'all out' until it touches down again.

Air Law.question: A continuous green light to an aircraft in flight means what?
options: Land immediately.
You may land.
Land when safe to do so.
Do not land.

Air Law.question: Which of the following is not recommended for flight?
options: Rain on the wings when the air temperature is close to freezing.
Frost on the wings.
Snow on the wings.
All of the above.

Air Law.question: What are the dimensions of an air traffic zone at an airfield where the longest runway is greater than 1850 metres?
options: 2000 feet above the airfield and 5 miles in diameter centred on the mid point of the longest runway.
2500 feet above the airfield and 5 miles in diameter centred on the mid point of the longest runway.
2000 feet above the airfield and 4 miles in diameter centred on the mid point of the longest runway.
2500 feet above the airfield and 4 miles in diameter centred on the mid point of the longest runway.

Air Law.question: An area on a 1:500,000 scale ICAO chart is annotated as being a Restricted area. What does this mean with regards to a glider in flight?
options: There is little relevance as the restrictions can not be complied with by a glider.
Flight within the published dimensions of the area must comply with the specified restrictions.
There shall be no thermalling within the restricted area.
Flight is restricted due to the density of traffic within the area.

Air Law.question: When landing close behind other aircraft, and in particular power aircraft, what should be your actions?
options: Over fly them and land long.
Land clear to their left.
You can land on either side.
Land clear to their right.

Air Law.question: Whilst approaching an airfield you notice a red flare fired from the control tower. What should your actions be?
options: Keep a good look out as there must be another aircraft near by.
Do not land, wait for permission.
Remain clear of the ATZ.
Continue with the circuit and watch for further instructions.

Air Law.question: What are the signal requirements from a glider pilot who is unable to release from the aerotow?
options: Fly out to the left and rock his wings.
Fly out to the right and rock his wings.
Try to break the rope.
Call on the radio and inform the tug pilot of the problem.

Air Law.question: If a solo glider pilot does not hold a CAA or equivalent medical or a current driving licence, what are the 'declaration of health' requirements?
options: Before first flying solo and on 50th, 60th and 65th birthdays.
Before first flying solo and every 10 years there after.
Before first flying solo and every 5 years there after.
Before first flying solo.

Air Law.question: What does a white dumbbell displayed in the signal square signify?
options: Both gliders and powered aircraft are operating from the airfield.
Movements of aircraft on the ground are confined to paved surfaces.
Winch launching and aerotows are in progress at the same time.
Paved areas are only available for powered aircraft. Gliders must land on the grass.

Air Law.question: Which statement is incorrect? You shall not fly -
options: Over or within 3000 ft of any open air assembly of more than 1000 people.
Below a height of 1500 ft above the highest fixed obstacle within 2000 ft.
Below a height of 2000 ft above any congested area of a city, town or settlement.
Below a height which would enable it to land clear of the area.

Air Law.question: Your cross country route takes a line through East Midlands CTA. What must be your actions during the flight?
options: Maintain VMC whilst in the CTA and keep a good look out.
Cross at the lowest possible level to avoid conflict with other traffic.
Call the ATC unit to inform them of your presence. You must hold a CAA RT license.
Cross at right angles, maintaining VMC.

Air Law.question: What is the tug pilot signalling when you see the rudder waggling whilst on tow?
options: Check your air brakes are not open or drag chute deployed and close or jettison as necessary.
You are to release immediately.
Wait until the tug tows you overhead the airfield and releases his end of the rope.
Expect the tug to slow down and continue at a slower speed.

Air Law.question: Other than persons by parachute in an emergency, which is most correct statement with reference to items permitted to be dropped from a glider in flight?
options: Ballast in the form of water only.
Tow ropes at an approved airfield.
Ballast in the form of fine sand only.
Ballast in the form of fine sand or water.

Air Law.question: What are the VMC minima required for gliders crossing airways?
options: Gliders are not allowed to cross airways at all except by local agreement.
1000m horizontally, 1500ft vertically and 8km visibility.
1500m horizontally, 1000ft vertically and 5km visibility.
1500m horizontally, 1000ft vertically and 8km visibility.

Air Law.question: An area on a 1:500,000 scale ICAO chart is annotated as being a Prohibited area. What does this mean with regards to gliders in flight?
options: There is little relevance as the area is only prohibited to powered aircraft.
Flight within the published dimensions of the area is prohibited.
Landing within the area is prohibited.
Flight is prohibited directly over head the area.

Air Law.question: What are the requirements to fly a newly rigged club aircraft?
options: Any pilot with the type endorsement in their log book.
You must be an instructor authorised by the CFI or deputy for that purpose.
Any instructor who is self authorising may carry out the task.
You must be authorised by the CFI or deputy for that purpose.

Air Law.question: What are the hours of day light (determined on the ground ) as defined for flying purposes?
options: Street lights 'off ' to street lights 'on'.
30 minutes before sunrise until 30 minutes after sunset.
30 minutes after sunrise until 30 minutes before sunset.
Sunrise until sunset.

Air Law.question: What are the requirements for keeping an accurate and up to date personal flying log book?
options: All pilots up to silver C and all instructors to prove their renewal requirements have been met.
All pilots regardless of hours and qualifications.
There are no requirements.
All pilots flying club owned aircraft to prove their currency.

Air Law.question: Whilst hill soaring which of the following statements is always true?
options: A glider wishing to overtake another should pass on its left side.
A glider wishing to overtake another should pass between it and the hill.
A glider wishing to overtake another should pass on its right side.
A glider wishing to overtake another should pass beneath it.

Air Law.question: Who has the right of way when two aircraft are landing together?
options: The faster aircraft.
The lower aircraft. ( unless the other is obviously in distress ).
The aircraft with the lower performance, but only if it is a two seater.
The least experienced pilot.

Air Law.question: What does a red and yellow striped arrow in the signal square of an airfield indicate?
options: The direction to follow the taxiway when recovering aircraft or gliders to park.
The direction of thermal turns for gliders.
The direction in which to vacate the runway after landing.
The direction of circuit in use.

Air Law.question: You are joining below a glider in a thermal. What are your actions?
options: Leave the thermal and find another.
Turn either direction as long as there is sufficient separation.
Turn in the same direction.
Remain at a safe distance below the other glider.

Air Law.question: Whilst planning a cross country flight you notice by reference to Notams that a purple airway has been established along your intended route during the period 1300 to 1500 Hrs. What should your actions be?
options: Continue as planned as it only applies to powered aircraft.
Change your route to remain clear of the airway during the notified period.
Continue as planned and cross the airway in VMC conditions at right angles.
Cross the airway as low as possible to avoid conflict with the royal aircraft.

Air Law.question: An area on a 1:500,000 scale ICAO chart is annotated as being a Danger area. What does this mean with regards to a glider in flight?
options: Flight within the published dimensions is restricted to periods where no dangerous activities are taking place.
Flight within the published dimensions may encounter activities dangerous to the glider or it's occupants.
There is little relevance to gliders as they may enter the area at will.
Flight within the published dimensions is prohibited.

Air Law.question: What does a double white cross ( ++ ) showing on a runway indicate?
options: An area where the runway is not available for landing.
Gliders and powered aircraft are using the same runway.
An area that shall only be used for the take off and landing of gliders.
An area that shall only be used for powered aircraft.

Air Law.question: What are the knock-on effects of a glider pilot's driving licence being revoked on medical grounds?
options: The pilot should inform his CFI within 30 days, who will make the appropriate decision.
The pilot should only fly solo. No passenger carrying allowed.
The pilot becomes unfit to fly gliders solo.
There are no problems and the pilot may continue as normal.

Air Law.question: What does a white 'T' in the signal square of an airfield denote?
options: Aircraft landing and taking off will do so in a direction parallel with the shaft of the 'T' and towards the cross arm.
The location of the tea cabin.
Gliders will be landing at right angles to that of powered aircraft.
Two runways are simultaneously in use.

Air Law.question: All BGA gliders must carry their approved identification markings. What are the requirements?
options: Displayed on the under side of the starboard wing.
Displayed on the fin and rudder and on the under side of the port wing.
Displayed on each side of the fin and rudder or on the fuselage in a substantially vertical plane. As large as practicable.
Displayed in the cockpit as a reminder when using the radio.

Air Law.question: Nose of tug to tail of glider, what is the maximum length of a tug / glider combination?
options: 150 yards in total.
150 metres in total.
100 yards in total.
100 metres in total.

Air Law.question: What is the minimum number of aerotows required by the tug pilot and glider pilot combined before launching may take place?
options: There is no minimum requirement as both are trained for their respective roles.

Air Law.question: What is the minimum equipment required in a glider used for aerobatic flying?
options: A five point harness and serviceable parachute.
An approved pitot tube extension to enable inverted flight.
An artificial horizon.
A serviceable G meter.

Air Law.question: What is the minimum age required before flying a glider solo in the United Kingdom?
options: 16 years.
14 years.
17 years.
15 years.

Air Law.question: The captain of any aircraft must satisfy himself that the intended flight can be made safely. In order to achieve this, it is an operational requirement that all gliding clubs provide what facilities?
options: Navigational information concerning temporary hazards and permanent changes.
A telephone link to the nearest ATC unit to inform them of the day's operation.
Meteorological forecasts for the use of club members.
Briefings for all cross country flights.

Air Law.question: Certain areas of class 'B' airspace have been annotated as 'Gliding areas'. The controlling Air Traffic agency requires a request to utilise the areas prior to gliders flying in this airspace. What are the time periods required for notification by telephone to the Air Traffic agency?
options: Two hours before intended use and five minutes prior to entry.
Twenty four hours before intended use and two hours prior to launch.
Two hours before launch and five minutes prior to entry.
Twenty four hours before intended use and two hours prior to entry.

Air Law.question: What are the rules for glider flights between FL 245 and FL 660?
options: There are no restrictions.
Only allowed in certain designated areas (windows) with prior permission.
No glider flights allowed due to the difficulties in controlling such airspace.
Only allowed during the hours of daylight as determined on the ground.

Airmanship.question: You have just landed your glider heavily. What are the correct actions?
options: No action needed
Inform the duty instructor before the aircraft flies again.
Continue flying as normal
Report to maintenance later

Airmanship.question: What will happen to the eyes when a pilot is operating at altitude or above cloud with an empty field of view?
options: Eyes focus at infinity
Eyes become tired quickly
Eyes will tend to focus very close
They will tend to focus at a point 1 to 2 metres away.

Airmanship.question: What will happen to the pilot who accepts a seating position that is too low in the cockpit?
options: They will lose from view a part of the approach area under the nose of the glider.
Seating position is irrelevant
They get better visibility
No effect on pilot's vision

Airmanship.question: On arrival at a strange airfield, you call on the notified frequency but get no reply. Your radio is serviceable, what should your actions be?
options: Abort landing
Land immediately
Continue with intended landing, watch for other traffic and follow suit, make relevant 'blind calls' on the radio.
Try a different frequency

Airmanship.question: What are the correct actions on joining a thermal?
options: Turn the same direction as other gliders and keep a good lookout.
Turn opposite to others
Maintain altitude without turning
Leave the thermal immediately

Airmanship.question: While ridge soaring with the hill on your right, you have to overtake another glider. What should your actions be?
options: Overtake on the left
Overtake on the right.
Signal before overtaking
Overtake only if the other pilot signals

Airmanship.question: While watching a glider about to launch with a senior instructor on board, you notice the air brakes are open. What should you do?
options: Ignore it
Signal the pilot
Stop the launch and bring it to the attention of the duty instructor.
Report after launch

Airmanship.question: You have flown every weekend for six months but missed the last four weekends. What should your actions be?
options: Fly as usual
Ask for a check flight or discuss your situation with the duty instructor.
No action needed
Practice solo flying

Airmanship.question: You notice on the daily inspection that the radio keeps blowing fuses. What should you do?
options: Replace the radio
Use it carefully
Get a qualified person to check the radio or clearly mark the radio 'u/s'.
Ignore and continue flying

Airmanship.question: A glider on a head on collision course with a military aircraft could have a very high closing speed. In such a situation, how would the image of the military aircraft appear to grow in size with decreasing range?
options: Image grows rapidly from the start
Image stays same size until close
Initial growth would be small until close to impact where growth would become rapid.
Image does not change size

Airmanship.question: As the winch cable is being attached you notice that the weak link is damaged. What should you do?
options: Proceed with caution
Have the suspect item changed before launching.
Ignore it
Report after flight

Airmanship.question: You are commencing a launch on the winch when you notice a glider turning in early to land up the field. Is this a problem?
options: No problem
Wait until they land
Warn them
Yes, if you have a launch failure you may have conflicting approaches.

Airmanship.question: You are converting to a new type. There is a cross wind and you are about to aerotow on the belly hook using an unusually short aerotow rope. What should you do?
options: Proceed normally
Ask for longer rope
Refuse the launch as it is getting dangerous to continue under the circumstances.
Adjust seating position

Airmanship.question: A glider and a military aircraft could have a closing speed of 600 kts. If the visibility is 5 miles, but the pilots only see each other at 3 miles, how much time would the pilots have to avoid collision?
options: About 20 seconds.
About 10 seconds
About 30 seconds
About 1 minute

Airmanship.question: You are breathing abnormally and showing symptoms similar to hypoxia at a low altitude where hypoxia would not be a consideration. What are you likely to be suffering from?
options: Hypoxia
Dehydration
Carbon monoxide poisoning
Hyperventilation.

Airmanship.question: There are certain vital actions to be taken in the event of a launch failure. Which of the following is the most correct statement?
options: Try to restart launch
Adopt a nose down attitude, regain a safe flying speed, release what is left of the cable and land according to your 'Eventualities' brief if possible.
Continue launching
Signal ground crew

Airmanship.question: On visiting a hill site, you read on the notice board a club rule stating a minimum height to leave the hill and return to site. Who does this apply to?
options: All pilots, regardless of experience and ability.
Only new pilots
Only experienced pilots
Only instructors

Airmanship.question: You are wire launching when you notice the parachute opening. What should be your immediate actions?
options: Ignore it
Continue launching
Treat the situation as a launch failure and take the appropriate actions.
Signal ground crew

Airmanship.question: Whilst flying downwind with a higher performance glider in front, and at about the same height as yourself, you notice he appears to be extending downwind further than you would like. What action should you take?
options: Speed up to catch up
Maintain course
Turn late
Turn in early and be prepared to land up the field if necessary in order to avoid a potential conflict.

Airmanship.question: After getting low on a cross country and choosing a field, you notice there is a stream along one side of it. What might this signify?
options: The field slopes down towards the stream
The field is flat
The field slopes away from the stream
No significance

Airmanship.question: Who is responsible for stopping a launch should anything be going wrong?
options: The launch point controller.
The duty instructor.
Anybody.
The pilot.

Airmanship.question: After Scuba diving, the guide lines are 'do not fly within 12 hours of swimming using compressed air and avoid flying for 24 hours if a depth of 30 feet has been exceeded'. Which risk is being kept to a minimum?
options: Hyperventilation.
Hypoxia.
Decompression sickness.
Sensory loss.

Airmanship.question: What is the function of the eustachian tube?
options: To allow the middle ear to drain freely.
To allow the middle ear to equalize with ambient pressure.
To allow the inner ear to equalize with ambient pressure.
To allow the inner ear to drain freely.

Airmanship.question: You are P2, flying mutually with a more experienced pilot who you consider has chosen an incorrect course of action which may endanger the glider. What should your actions be?
options: Accept this course of action as the other pilot is P1.
Question the action of the pilot, only if you think the handling pilot will listen.
Take control from the handling pilot and rectify the situation.
Always express any doubts that you may have.

Airmanship.question: On a cross country flight in August you are faced with an out landing. Assuming no obstructions and fields of adequate size, which of the following would be the correct choice?
options: A field with cows in one corner.
A field of standing corn.
A field with sheep in one corner.
A stubble field that has a border ploughed around it.

Airmanship.question: In which direction should all turns be made when hill soaring?
options: Away from the hill.
Left.
Right.
Same as the glider in front.

Airmanship.question: You are about to land out. Which of the following is the best option, when the only suitable field has a slope in it, and the wind is up the slope?
options: Land down hill, into wind.
Land across the slope, and cross wind.
Land up hill, down wind.
Land diagonally down slope to give the longest ground run with an into wind component.

Airmanship.question: You are on aerotow when you notice the rudder of the tug waggling from side to side. What should your actions be?
options: Check air brakes are closed and jettison tail chute if it has deployed.
Check air brakes are closed.
Release immediately.
Fly out to the left and rock your wings in reply.

Airmanship.question: You are faced with a field landing. You know the 4000' wind is 240 degrees, 20 kts. What is the surface wind most likely to be?
options: 240 degrees, 10 kts.
Greater than 240 degrees, less than 20 kts.
Less than 240 degrees, greater than 20 kts.
Less than 240 degrees, less than 20 kts.

Airmanship.question: Which of the following is most correct when entering a turn?
options: Lookout first then turn.
Lookout, look over the nose, then turn.
Ensure it is clear in the direction of the turn, then turn.
Start the turn, then lookout in the same direction.

Airmanship.question: What actions should be taken when flying through an area of sink?
options: Slow down so as to reduce the rate of descent.
Increase speed so as to spend as little time in the sink as possible.
Continue as normal because the lift on the other side of the sink will compensate for the height loss.
Slow down and turn away from the sink.

Airmanship.question: What is the approximate time required to eliminate 1 unit of alcohol from the blood?
options: 30 minutes.
60 minutes.
90 minutes.
120 minutes.

Airmanship.question: When keeping a good lookout, how is the most effective scanning achieved?
options: A series of short, regularly spaced eye movements, progressing across the field of view.
Rapidly and smoothly sweeping the entire field of view.
A random scan of the most likely areas of conflicting traffic.
Alternating between three or four different areas.

Airmanship.question: During a solo flight you notice the handling appears to be different from the last time you flew it. What action, if any, should you take after landing?
options: None.
Check the log book to see if any ballast weight has been added or removed.
Bring it to the attention of the duty instructor before it flies again.
Let the next person to fly the glider know of the problem.

Airmanship.question: While flying in cloud you notice the ASI reading slowly reduces to zero. What is the most likely cause?
options: You are fully stalled.
There is ice in the static system.
There is water in the pitot system.
There is ice in the pitot system.

Airmanship.question: You are down wind to land at your home site when you are overtaken by a higher performance glider with only one airbrake extended. Who has right of way?
options: The other glider, as there is an emergency.
You have right of way as the lower performing glider.
The other glider, due to its faster circuit speed.
You have right of way, even though there is an emergency in progress.

Airmanship.question: You are half way up the winch launch when the speed increases above max winch launch. What should be your immediate actions?
options: Lower the nose slightly and give the too fast signal. If, after a few seconds, you are still too fast, then abandon the launch.
Pull back so as to load the winch and reduce the speed.
Release immediately.
Maintain the climbing attitude and wave off.

Airmanship.question: You are soaring in a moderate westerly wind, a ridge which runs north west to south east when orographic cloud forms all around. Which compass heading and speed should you fly?
options: 180 degrees at best L/D.
270 degrees at min sink.
245 degrees at min sink.
245 degrees at best L/D.

Airmanship.question: You are about to join a thermal with two gliders circling in opposite directions. Which way do you turn?
options: Same direction as the higher glider.
Same direction as the lower glider.
Either direction as the thermal would seem to be a free for all.
Same direction as the closer glider.

Airmanship.question: You are about to land as there is thunder storm activity from a Cb close by. What should you particularly be aware of?
options: Lightning flashes which may blind temporarily.
Rapid changes in wind strength and direction.
Reducing visibility due to low cloud base.
Reduction in performance due to wet wings.

Airmanship.question: While hill soaring with the hill on your left, you meet a higher performance glider coming the other way. Who has right of way and what actions should you take?
options: The other glider has right of way and you should turn right.
You have right of way being the lower performing glider but should be prepared to give way.
You have right of way but the rules of the ridge dictate that you should give way.
Neither has right of way and both should turn right.

Airmanship.question: Whilst in a straight glide you notice another glider on your right at about the same height. The bearing relative to you is remaining constant and the separation is reducing. What actions should you take?
options: None, as you have right of way.
Take avoiding action as the other glider has right of way.
Wait to see what develops but be prepared to take avoiding action.
Increase speed to try and out glide the other glider.

Airmanship.question: A pilot is faced with a field landing into a slightly down sloping field. What is most likely to happen?
options: A shallower approach than intended will be flown.
A normal approach will be flown, as intended.
A steeper approach than normal will be flown.
An under shoot will be flown.

Airmanship.question: What is the main cause of motion sickness?
options: Direct effect of movement on the stomach.
The mismatch between visual and vestibular sensory inputs.
Changes in blood pressure produced by motion.
Long periods of 'head inside the cockpit'.

Airmanship.question: After an aerobatic session in a semi-aerobatic glider, the accelerometer reads +4g and -2.5g. What action do you need to take, if any?
options: None, as the limit loads have not been exceeded.
Inform the duty instructor before it flies again, as the placard limits have been exceeded.
Make an entry in the DI book to record the applied loads.
Inform the CFI at the end of the day.

Airmanship.question: On returning to your home airfield after a long flight, the duty instructor alerts you on the radio, of a strong wind gradient. What should you do?
options: Watch for heavy sink on the approach.
Increase airspeed well above the normal and be prepared for a rapid reduction in airspeed close to the ground.
Be prepared to use less airbrake on the later part of the approach.
All of the above.

Airmanship.question: You are climbing in good wave lift, but your glider is not equipped with oxygen. At what height is it recommended you should abandon your climb?
options: 8,000 feet.

Airmanship.question: While on a cross country, you are continually correcting your heading to the right in order to reach your goal. What might this signify?
options: The wind is from the right of track.
The wind is from the left of track.
There is probably a magnetic anomaly affecting the compass.
Magnetic variation is particularly strong at this time.

Airmanship.question: What disadvantages, if any, would there be in getting too close to cloud base?
options: You may lose sight of your next thermal.
You may inadvertently enter cloud and exit in the wrong direction.
You may inadvertently enter cloud and ice up sufficiently enough to lose out on performance, making the extra height gain worthless.
All of the above.

Airmanship.question: How would you check your chosen field for slope?
options: Look for a lack of crop.
Look for sheep where cattle would normally be.
Check the map for contours.
Fly around the field checking visually for slope.

Airmanship.question: What are the stall recovery actions?
options: Stick forward, regain flying speed, level the wings (if necessary) and return to the normal gliding attitude.
Regain flying speed and return to the normal gliding attitude.
Stick forward, wings level, regain flying speed and return to the normal gliding attitude.
Stick forward, regain flying speed and return to the normal gliding attitude.

Airmanship.question: What is the correct mnemonic for the glider pre manoeuvre checks?
options: HASL ( height, area, security and lookout.)
HASSL ( height, airframe, security, straps and lookout.)
HASSLL ( height, airframe, straps, security, location and lookout.)
HASELL ( height, airframe, security, engine, location and lookout.)

Airmanship.question: When carrying out the pre manoeuvre checks, what does the airframe part of the check call for?
options: Ensure that the airframe is cleared for the manoeuvres to be flown.
It acts as a reminder of the 'g' limits.
A check of placarded limiting speeds and loads and that the glider is cleared for the manoeuvres and that the correct configuration is used, i.e. flap settings etc.
A check of the limiting speeds such as Vne and Max Manoeuvre.

Airmanship.question: Why is it important to judge height without reference to an altimeter when flying a circuit?
options: Altimeter errors and pressure changes render the altimeter inaccurate and unreliable.
So as to be able to land safely, should the altimeter fail.
It is a requirement for the Bronze C flying check.
You may have forgotten to return the subscale to the correct setting.

Airmanship.question: When should a positive control check be carried out?
options: Before each flight.
Only after rigging the glider.
Before each days flying commences.
Before each days flying and immediately after rigging the glider.

Airmanship.question: What effect would 50 foot trees on the down wind boundary of your chosen field have on your landing run, assuming you would normally touch down just inside the field perimeter?
options: There will be no effect what so ever.
They will move the touch down point 500 feet further up the field.
They will move the touch down point 50 feet further up the field.
They will cause a wind shadow in the first 500 feet of the field.

Airmanship.question: A tobacco smoker, compared to a non-smoker, is subjected to altitudes at which the onset of hypoxia is likely. What will probably be the experience of the smoker?
options: Initial symptoms will be experienced at a lower cabin altitude.
Initial symptoms will be experienced at a higher cabin altitude.
Initial symptoms will be experienced at the same cabin altitude.
Initial symptoms will be experienced at the same cabin altitude, but worse.

Airmanship.question: You are suffering from a common cold. What is the most likely event whilst flying?
options: The reduced pressure whilst flying will ease any discomfort caused by the infection.
Changes in pressure are likely to cause discomfort.
There should be no effects whilst flying.
You may feel a little dizzy but may ignore the symptoms and continue to fly.

Airmanship.question: Is it important to read NOTAMs before flying cross country?
options: No, if there is any problems, the duty instructor will point them out.
Yes, it is the pilots responsibility to familiarise themselves with notices.
No, they only apply to royal flights and the Red Arrows.
Yes, but only when planning to fly through controlled airspace.

Airmanship.question: You are final gliding back to your home airfield and wish to fly a competition type finish. You call on the radio for permission but get no reply, what should be your actions?
options: Continue as planned, flying must have stopped.
Continue as planned, but keep a lookout for other gliders.
Change to a more conservative type finish followed by a normal circuit.
Keep trying on the radio until you get a reply

Airmanship.question: What are the correct actions when a glider on your left is converging on your flight path?
options: Although you have right of way, take avoiding action early if necessary.
No action required as you have right of way.
Take avoiding action, as the other glider has right of way.
Increase speed so as to out glide the other aircraft.

Airmanship.question: You are final gliding to your home airfield when you realise that you are unsure of reaching the airfield. What is the best course of action?
options: Continue as planned as you will be able to dolphin the last bit home.
Choose a field and land.
Change course and fly towards the nearest thermal.
Continue towards the airfield, but only if there is an alternative landing area available between you and the airfield.

Airmanship.question: You are in the process of winch launching when there is a delay at the winch. Your canopy has begun to mist up but you have the cable attached. What is the best course of action?
options: Continue, as the canopy will clear on the launch.
Release the cable and clear the canopy before launching, a launch failure could be disastrous with poor visibility.
Continue, making use of the DV panel as required.
Open the DV panel and all vents in order to clear the canopy once the launch begins.

Airmanship.question: Having consumed a small amount of alcohol, how long should you wait before flying?
options: 4 Hrs.
6 Hrs.
8 Hrs.
10 Hrs.

Airmanship.question: You are on medication, the effects of which you are unsure. What is the correct thing to do?
options: Continue to fly.
Do not take the medication whilst airborne.
Wait a while after taking the medication to see if there is any reason not to fly.
Do not fly. If in doubt seek medical advice.

Airmanship.question: Who is responsible for stopping a launch?
options: The duty instructor.
Anybody.
The pilot.
The wing tip holder.

Airmanship.question: A Glider overtaking another in the UK shall follow which rule?
options: Always overtake from above.
Overtake on either side.
Always overtake on the right.
Always overtake on the left.

Airmanship.question: Which of the following is correct when 2 aircraft are on a converging course?
options: The aircraft which has the other on its right has the right of way.
The aircraft at the lower altitude has the right of way.
The aircraft which has the other on its right shall give way.
The slower aircraft must give way.

Airmanship.question: What does hyperventilation lead to?
options: A shortage of oxygen.
Blackouts.
Greyouts.
An excess of oxygen.

Airmanship.question: What effects will cigarette smoking have on a pilot?
options: It will reduce the amount of oxygen in the blood.
It will increase the amount of oxygen in the blood.
It will increase the pilots decision time.
It will increase the pilots awareness.

Airmanship.question: What name is given when the body is suffering from low temperatures?
options: Hypoxia.
Hypothermia.
Hypoglycaemic.
Anoxia.

Airmanship.question: What happens to the amount of oxygen that diffuses across the lung membranes when at high altitudes?
options: It remains the same.
It increases.
It reduces due to temperature reductions.
It reduces due to pressure reductions.

Airmanship.question: What happens to the percentage content of oxygen in the air as altitude increases?
options: It decreases due to decrease in temperature.
It increases.
It remains the same.
It decreases due to decrease in pressure.

Airmanship.question: The respiratory process is governed by chemical receptors in the brain which monitor the levels of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Which of the following is the most accurate statement with respect to a healthy body?
options: The body is more sensitive to changes in oxygen than carbon dioxide.
The body is more sensitive to changes in carbon dioxide than oxygen.
The body is more sensitive to changes in the gas registering the least amount.
The body is more sensitive to changes in the gas registering the largest amount.

Airmanship.question: Which of the following list of signs and symptoms are associated with hypoxia? 1. Personality changes. 2. Impaired judgement. 3. Muscular impairment. 4. Memory impairment. 5. Sensory loss. 6. Impairment of consciousness.
options: Items 1 and 2 only.
Items 1 to 3 only.
Items 1 to 4 only.
All of the above items.

Airmanship.question: Which of the following should be carried out before washing a glider?
options: Ensure that the airbrakes are locked in.
Ensure that the control column is restrained by the harness.
Ensure that the wheelbrake is on.
Ensure that the aircraft is serviceable.

Airmanship.question: Which 2 conditions are particularly detrimental to GRP structure?
options: Polar Continental and polar maritime air masses.
Rain and strong winds.
Moisture and solar radiation.
Low humidity and light winds.

Airmanship.question: Why should care be taken when using a hose to rinse down a glider after washing?
options: Because there is a water shortage.
To ensure that water is not forced into orifices.
To minimise soap dilution.
To ensure personnel don’t get wet.

Airmanship.question: In a motor glider, which type of poisoning may result due to a faulty exhaust system?
options: Carbon monoxide.
Carbon dioxide.
Hypoxia.
Blood.

Airmanship.question: What problems exist, if any, detecting carbon monoxide in the cockpit of a motor glider?
options: It is easily recognisable because of its peculiar odour.
It is easily recognisable because of its peculiar colour.
It is difficult to recognise because it is odourless and colourless.
It is impossible to detect.

Airmanship.question: What happens to the amount of oxygen available as altitude increases?
options: Decreases due to decrease in air density.
Remains the same.
Increases due to increase in density.
Becomes diluted.

Airmanship.question: Lack of oxygen may cause a particularly dramatic effect in a pilot. What is this known as?
options: Anoxia.
Hypoxia.
Suffocation.
Hyperventilation.

Meteorology.question: At the passage of a cold front, what will the wind do?
options: Veer and decrease.
Back and decrease.
Veer and increase.
Back and increase.

Meteorology.question: What type of cloud is associated with moist air flowing over a hill?
options: Anabatic cloud.
Radiation cloud.
Advection cloud.
Orographic cloud.

Meteorology.question: What does ‘Buys Ballots’ law state of the northern hemisphere?
options: If you stand with your back to the wind the low is on your left.
If you stand with your back to the wind the low is on your right.
Low pressure systems rotate clockwise when viewed from above.
Temperature decreases with height at a rate of 1.7 degrees per 1000 ft.

Meteorology.question: What is usually the first sign of an approaching warm front in the summer months?
options: Cumulo nimbus rapidly approaching from the west.
High layer cloud slowly approaching, with weakening soaring conditions.
Rain, heavy at first, slowly dying out as the front approaches.
Increasing winds, but little prospect of rain.

Meteorology.question: What weather associated with cumulo nimbus is considered to be the worst hazard when landing a glider?
options: Lightning, blinding pilots and damaging gliders.
Heavy rain leaving the wings performance seriously degraded.
Icing, degrading performance and making vision through the canopy difficult.
Increased wind strength together with rapid direction changes, making landing in particular, very difficult.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of radiation fog?
options: Warm dry air flowing over cold wet ground.
Warm moist air flowing over cold dry ground, being cooled from beneath.
The sun warming cold moist ground.
Moist air cooling over night to below the dew point with light winds.

Meteorology.question: In the lower atmosphere, what is regarded as being the accepted reduction of pressure with increase in height?
options: 30 mb per 1000 feet.
1 mb per 30 feet.
1mb per 1000 feet.
30 mb per 10,000 feet.

Meteorology.question: What is wind gradient?
options: Rapid changes in wind direction with height.
Turbulence, due to the fast flow close to the ground.
The difference in pressure between a high and a low.
Rapid reduction in wind strength close to the ground.

Meteorology.question: A high pressure inversion in summer will have what effects on soaring?
options: Prevention of the formation of thermals.
Prevention of the formation of cumulus, once the inversion is below the dew point.
Increase the overall average thermal strength due to lack of cloud shadow.
Allow thermals to continue later into the evening.

Meteorology.question: What is the overlapping of a warm and cold front called?
options: An occlusion.
A col.
A depression.
An inversion.

Meteorology.question: What is the name given to a line drawn on a map joining places of equal pressure?
options: An Isobar.
A millibar.
A pressure gradient.
An Isogonal.

Meteorology.question: Whilst flying cross country you notice that the cumulus are getting larger and some have developed an anvil shape at the top. What weather is most likely to follow?
options: Rapidly improving soaring conditions.
Deteriorating soaring conditions due to the increase in cloud shadow.
Thunder storms or rain showers leading to unsoarable areas.
Wide spread rain.

Meteorology.question: What effect in general, does a building high pressure system have on the level of an inversion?
options: The level rises as the high pressure system approaches.
The level remains the same, however, the dew point does rise above it.
The level falls slowly as the high pressure system approaches.
There is no effect on the inversion, however, the cloud base will lower.

Meteorology.question: Where might you find rotor cloud?
options: Over hill tops and in the lee of hills in association with wave systems.
Along a sea breeze front in association with strong lift and sink.
In front of orographic cloud.
Underneath cumulus nimbus clouds in association with down draughts.

Meteorology.question: What happens to visibility and temperature at the passage of a cold front?
options: Visibility increases and temperature decreases.
Visibility decreases and temperature decreases.
Visibility increases and temperature increases.
Visibility decreases and temperature increases.

Meteorology.question: What are the effects of diurnal variation on the soaring day?
options: The wind increases at the start of the day and decreases at the end of the day.
The wind veers and increases at the start of the day and backs and decreases at the end of the day.
The wind backs and increases at the start of the day and veers and decreases at the end of the day.
The wind veers and decreases at the start of the day and backs and increases at the end of the day.

Meteorology.question: The forecast wind is due to veer by 30 degrees during the morning. If the wind direction is a north easterly at the start, what will be the wind direction after it has veered, assuming the forecast is correct?
options: 015 degrees.
045 degrees.
075 degrees.
225 degrees.

Meteorology.question: Due to a high pressure system the prevailing wind across the UK is from the south west on a summers day. What name best describes this wind?
options: Tropical maritime.
Tropical continental.
Polar maritime.
Polar continental.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of advection fog?
options: Warm dry air, flowing over cold wet ground.
Warm moist air, flowing over a cold surface, being cooled from beneath.
The sun, warming cold moist ground.
Warm moist air, flowing over a hill or ridge.

Meteorology.question: In the atmosphere, air flows from high pressure to low pressure in an attempt to reach equilibrium. Why then, does the wind flow anti clockwise round a low pressure when viewed from above?
options: Due to the Earths rotation and the coriander effect.
Due to the Earths rotation and the Coriolis effect.
Due to the jet stream in association with the low.
Due to temperature gradients within the low creating friction between layers

Meteorology.question: In May a deep trough is forecast to pass through the local area during the day. What would be the most likely associated weather?
options: Excellent soaring, particularly after the trough has passed.
Poor soaring due to slowly deteriorating weather.
Particularly violent weather at the passage of the trough, including strong winds, heavy rain and Cb activity.
Better soaring during the passage of the trough, but otherwise a poor day.

Meteorology.question: In August, a weak ridge is forecast across the country the day after a cold front has passed through. What would be the most likely weather?
options: Poor soaring as the ridge will reduce the instability from the cold front.
Good soaring as a ridge reduces the instability behind the cold front preventing over convevtion.
Poor soaring due to over convection.
Deteriorating soaring conditions due to the lowering inversion.

Meteorology.question: What is the area, like a saddle on a mountain ridge, bounded by two high pressure systems and two low pressure systems called?
options: An occlusion.
A trough.
A ridge.
A Col.

Meteorology.question: What is a cause of temperature inversion?
options: Descending air warming due to compression and resting on the cooler airmass beneath.
Pollution in the lower atmosphere reflecting the suns energy.
Uneven heating of the atmosphere due to instability.
Uneven heating of the atmosphere due to stability.

Meteorology.question: You are flying from a site in the UK where the ridge faces south west. A depression is forecast to track close to the area over the next few days. Where would the centre of the depression need to be, in relation to the ridge site, for the ridge to work best?
options: Due south.
North east.
South west.
North west.

Meteorology.question: What is a visibility of more than 1000 metres but less than 2000 metres known as?
options: Fog.
Mist.
Haze.
Poor visibility.

Meteorology.question: A sea breeze front has been forecast to penetrate inland beyond one of your chosen turning points. Assuming this takes place before you get there, what would be the expected weather conditions as you approach the TP?
options: Improving soaring conditions until the TP has been rounded.
Deteriorating through the front, but much better round the TP.
Improved at the front, but weak soaring, if any, around the TP.
There will be little change to soaring conditions as most fronts of this type are weak.

Meteorology.question: What is the approximate rate of change of temperature with height for the dry adiabatic lapse rate?
options: 3 degrees Celsius loss per 1000 feet height gain.
2 degrees Celsius loss per 1000 feet height gain.
1.5 degrees Celsius loss per 1000 feet height gain.
1 degree Celsius loss per 1000 feet height gain.

Meteorology.question: When an air mass rises it cools at a given rate. Cooler air cannot hold as much water vapour as warmer air and therefore eventually becomes saturated. What is this point called, and what happens there?
options: The saturated lapse point, and cloud vertical development starts here.
The dew point, and cloud vertical development stops here.
The saturated lapse point, and cloud vertical development stops here.
The dew point, and cloud vertical development starts here.

Meteorology.question: What are the three main stages called in the life cycle of a thunderstorm?
options: The cumulus stage, the mature stage and the dissipating stage.
The cumulus stage, the mature stage and the precipitation stage.
The cumulus stage, the precipitation stage and the dissipating stage.
The precipitation stage, the gust front stage and the dissipating stage.

Meteorology.question: What is meant by the term ‘stable air mass’?
options: The pressure is high, and therefore no thermal activity will be present.
The environmental lapse rate is less than the dry adiabatic lapse rate.
The airmass is dry, therefore no thermals or cumulus cloud will form.
The environmental lapse rate is greater than the dry adiabatic lapse rate.

Meteorology.question: What is the name given to the wind effect that increases temperature and raises cloud base in the lee of a hill?
options: The orographic wind effect.
The foehn wind effect.
The geostrophic wind effect.
The lee wave rotor wind effect.

Meteorology.question: What is the official definition of fog?
options: Visibility reduced to below 5000 metres.
Visibility reduced to below 1000 metres.
Visibility reduced to below 2000 metres.
Visibility reduced to below 3000 metres.

Meteorology.question: Icing effects, in particular, aerodynamics. What other effects does icing have on a glider?
options: Pitot tubes & static vents may become blocked.
Weight is increased which may alter the C of G position.
Weight is increased which may alter the C of G position and pitot tubes & statics may become blocked.
Weight is increased which may alter the C of G position, pitot tubes & statics may become blocked and radio communications may be degraded.

Meteorology.question: A large depression is centred over the north of Scotland. What will be the wind direction over central & southern England?
options: From the North.
From the East.
From the South.
From the West.

Meteorology.question: Three conditions are necessary for a thunderstorm to develop. If deep instability is forecast with a high moisture content, what is the third condition required?
options: Light winds and little cloud shadow.
Light winds aloft so as to allow vertical development of the cumulus.
An already high cloud base with large cumulus developing.
A trigger action such as a front forcing the air aloft, a mountain forcing the air aloft or strong heating of the lower air mass.

Meteorology.question: What is the approximate rate of change of temperature with height for the saturated adiabatic lapse rate?
options: 3 degrees Celsius loss per 1000 feet height gain.
2 degrees Celsius loss per 1000 feet height gain.
1.5 degrees Celsius loss per 1000 feet height gain.
1 degree Celsius loss per 1000 feet height gain.

Meteorology.question: What causes hail to form?
options: Rain freezing as it falls through a cold atmosphere.
Rain falling through a temperature inversion.
Water molecules freezing in the up draughts of a Cb, growing with each cycle until too heavy to be sustained by the rising air.
Ice crystals in the upper cloud falling to the ground before they have time to melt.

Meteorology.question: Is it possible for thermals to develop under an extensive layer of strato-cumulus?
options: Yes, if there is sufficient instability in the atmosphere.
No, there will be insufficient energy from the sun reaching the ground.
No, strato-cumulus normally forms in stable conditions.
No, even where the layer cloud in broken or thin enough to allow the sun’s energy through, insufficient energy will reach the ground.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of a sea breeze front?
options: Sea heating more quickly than the land which causes the air to rise over the sea. This in turn leads to advection and the sea breeze.
Cooler sea air mixing with an offshore breeze creates the frontal system.
Land heating more quickly than the sea which causes the air to rise overland which in turn leads to advection and the sea breeze.
Warm air over the sea against cooler land air creates the frontal system.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of katabatic winds?
options: Cooling air becomes more dense and therefore sinks. At night this sinking air will flow down hills and through valleys creating the wind.
Warm air becomes less dense and rises. With the sun on a slope during the day, warm air flows up hill creating the wind.
Exhaust air descending in a high pressure system leads to the creation of the wind.
The wind blowing over a ridge creates a low pressure on the leeward slope which in turn sucks air out of the leeward valley creating the wind.

Meteorology.question: What is the name given to the point at which water vapour condenses, and what is the required humidity?
options: The dew point and can occur at any percentage saturation.
The saturation level and can occur above 90% saturation.
The dew point and requires 100% saturation.
The evaporation point and requires 100% saturation.

Meteorology.question: What is the ICAO standard altimeter setting?
options: What ever the regional QNH is on the flight.
What ever the forecast QNH is on the day.
1013.2 millibars, ( hectopascals ), regardless of local conditions.
1013.2 millibars, (hectopascals ), unless the regional QNH is lower.

Meteorology.question: When an altimeter scale is set to QNH, what does it indicate?
options: Height above the ground.
Altitude above the ground.
Altitude, which is height above 1013.2 millibars, ( hectopascals).
Altitude, which is height above mean sea level.

Meteorology.question: What conditions are usually associated with warm dry air from the continent flowing over the UK in the summer?
options: Convective cloud, showers and thunderstorms.
Stratus, sea fog and drizzle.
Warm with clear skies.
Warm with hazy weather.

Meteorology.question: Which of the following is the most accurate definition of the adiabatic lapse rate?
options: The rate of change of temperature due to expansion with increasing height, taking into account the moisture content, i.e. dry or saturated.
The rate of change of temperature with increasing height.
The rate of change of pressure with height, taking into account the moisture content, i.e. dry or saturated.
The rate of change of pressure with height, taking into account air temperature.

Meteorology.question: The surface temperature is 20 degrees and the trigger temperature is 24 degrees centigrade. Assuming the environmental lapse rate 2 degrees, the dry adiabatic lapse rate is 3 degrees, what height will the thermal go to?
options: 2000 feet.
3000 feet.
4000 feet.
5000 feet.

Meteorology.question: At what height is the surface wind measured?
options: 20 metres. (60 feet).
10 metres. ( 30 feet).
5 metres. (15 feet).
3 metres. (10 feet).

Meteorology.question: An anticyclone may be described as the atmosphere at rest. What does the air mass consist of?
options: Slowly subsiding air flowing anticlockwise in the northern hemisphere.
Slowly rising air flowing clockwise in the northern hemisphere.
Rapidly subsiding air flowing anticlockwise in the northern hemisphere.
Slowly subsiding air flowing clockwise in the northern hemisphere.

Meteorology.question: What would be an indication of a strong wind on a weather Chart?
options: Isobars close together indicating a slack pressure gradient.
Isobars close together indicating a steep pressure gradient.
Contours close together indicating a steep wind gradient.
Isobars far apart indicating a steep pressure gradient.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of the Coriolis effect?
options: Rotation of the earth.
Vertical air movements within a high.
Pressure differences.
Vertical air movements within a low.

Meteorology.question: Which direction does air flow around a high pressure in the northern hemisphere?
options: Anticlockwise.
Clockwise.
From low pressure to high pressure.
South.

Meteorology.question: What is the name given to lines depicting points of equal pressure on a synoptic chart?
options: Isogonals.
Isobars.
Contours.
Isometrics.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of anabatic winds?
options: Cooling air becomes more dense and therefore sinks. At night this sinking air will flow down hills and through valleys creating the wind.
Warm air becomes less dense and rises. With the sun on a slope during the day, warm air flows up hill creating the wind.
Exhaust air descending in a high pressure system leads to the creation of the wind.
The wind blowing over a ridge creates a low pressure on the leeward slope which in turn sucks air out of the leeward valley creating the wind.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of Hoar frost?
options: Dry air in contact with the ground being cooled below freezing.
Dry air in contact with the ground being saturated.
Moist air in contact with any surface being cooled below freezing.
Moist air in contact with the sea being cooled below freezing.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of hill Fog?
options: Moist air forced uphill and its temperature reduced to below the dew point.
Dry air forced up hill and its temperature increased to the saturation point.
Moist air forced down hill and its temperature increased to the saturation point.
Moist air forced up hill and its temperature increased above the dew point.

Meteorology.question: What are the values of the dry adiabatic lapse rate (DALR) and saturated adiabatic lapse rate (SALR)?
options: DALR = 3 C per 1000 ft, SALR = 2 C per 1000 ft.
DALR = 3 F per 1000 ft, SALR = 2 F per 1000 ft.
DALR = 3 C per 100 ft, SALR = 1.5 C per 100 ft.
DALR = 3 C per 1000 ft, SALR = 1.5 C per 1000 ft.

Meteorology.question: What is the cause of wind?
options: The coriolis force.
Pressure differences trying to reach equilibrium.
The rotation of the earth.
Air mass modification.

Meteorology.question: Cloud amounts are reported in Oktas. Clouds are also divided into 10 main classifications. What does the information 3/8 SC, 6/8 CS, 4/8 AC indicate?
options: 3/8 Stratocumulus, 3/4 cover Cirrostratus, 1/2 cover Altocumulus.
3/8 Stratus, 3/4 cover Cirrostratus, 4/8 cover Altocirrus.
3/8 Cumulostratus, 6/8 Stratocumulus, 4/8 Altocumulosaltus.
3/8 Stratocumulus, 6/8 cirrostratus, 4/8 Altrocirrolus.

Meteorology.question: What are the most severe weather conditions causing destructive winds, squalls, heavy rain and hail, generally associated with?
options: Thunderstorms and line squalls over land.
Slow moving cold fronts over the sea.
Fast moving warm fronts over the land.
Fast moving cold fronts over the sea.

Meteorology.question: What is a squall line usually associated with?
options: A fast moving warm front.
An occluded front.
A fast moving cold front.
A stationary front.

Meteorology.question: What is an Isobar?
options: A line drawn on a synoptic chart joining points of equal height above mean sea level.
A line drawn on a synoptic chart joining points of equal pressure at mean sea level.
A line drawn on a synoptic chart joining points of equal pressure at 1013.2 Mb.
A line drawn on a synoptic chart joining points of equal temperature corrected to a standard atmosphere.

Meteorology.question: What would be a typical characteristic of a Tropical Continental airmass in winter?
options: Warm and fairly dry.
Warm and moist with low cloud, rain/drizzle.
Cool and moist perhaps with hail and thunder.
Very cold and dry.

Meteorology.question: What is a surface visibility of less than 1000 metres classed as?
options: Fog.
Haze.
Mist.
VMC.

Meteorology.question: Which condition is most likely to affect gliding within a stable air mass?
options: Good visibility at the surface, poor at height.
Moderate turbulence at low level with good visibility.
Smoke, haze and dust concentrated in lower levels resulting in poor visibility.
Steady drizzle with very poor visibility.

Meteorology.question: What is the name given to the ratio of existing water vapour in the air, as compared to the maximum amount that could exist at a given temperature?
options: The condensation level.
The saturation level.
The relative humidity.
The dew point.

Meteorology.question: What causes the wind to increase and veer with increase in height?
options: Geostationary forces and decreasing air pressure.
Geostrophic forces and surface friction.
Geostrophic forces and increasing air pressure.
Geostationary forces and surface tension.

Meteorology.question: What is the correct name given to a weather map?
options: Isobar Chart.
Ordinance Chart.
